poem:
Title: The Songbird's Echo

Unchanged melody
echoes golden years,
time-lacquered now
in delicate fragility.
Warwick's voice, a pear
ready for harvest, ripens.
Through thinning texture,
heart notes burgeon,
revealing the marrow
of her enduring song,
"accept me for what I am"-
ages in the dusk of her echo.
Old lyrics, new fragility,
a truth still glistening in the sun.
The songbird still sings,
aged but ever grand.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dionne Warwick review – fascinating look back is a little short on songs In 1962, 21-year-old Dionne Warwick sang the Burt Bacharach and Hal David-penned Don’t Make Me Over to launch a career spanning six Grammys and 100m sales. More than six decades later, the soul legend opens with it here – although at 83 her voice understandably sounds more frail and vulnerable, giving new and moving meaning to the line “accept me for what". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Dionne Warwick review – fascinating look back is a little short on songs In 1962, 21-year-old Dionne Warwick sang the Burt Bacharach and Hal David-penned Don’t Make Me Over to launch a career spanning six Grammys and 100m sales. More than six decades later, the soul legend opens with it here – although at 83 her voice understandably sounds more frail and vulnerable, giving new and moving meaning to the line “accept me for what
